dialogue.text: Yes I think guidance duplication should be avoided. I'd like to see how we can also synthesize guidance for Attributes, as well as Deliverables - should deliverables be their own first-class registry item?

Proposed Universal Registry Architecture: Decouple deliverables into registry/deliverables.json. Oracle will dynamically synthesize guidance by aggregating from protocols, standards, attributes, and deliverables registries. Promoted to Backlog as FEAT_UNIVERSAL_ORACLE.

ideas.title: High-Fidelity Deliverable Standards & Semantic Schemas
ideas.description: Upgrade the Deliverable Registry to use full JSON Schema standards. This enables: 1) Strict type enforcement for automated audits. 2) Embedded semantic guidance (descriptions/examples) for ZK training. 3) Standardized metadata for efficient knowledge retrieval by future entities.

dialogue.text: Refine - the primary goals of this IDEA is not only to improve detail, fidelity and verbosity of deliverables - but to promote standardisation of content that can be persisted to the system for future ZK entities to interpret. Do you have any suggestions to expand this?

Proposed expansion: 1) Semantic Annotation (Why/Examples) to make schemas teaching instruments. 2) Machine-Readable Context (Meta tags) for future retrieval. 3) Persistence Standardization (Strict path patterns). 4) Versioned Schemas for evolutionary compatibility.
Yes log. I like the above expansion. We should also include a discussion on strict naming for persisted delierables - i.e a 'report' should be a 'kind' and there should be sub-kinds etc..
Included Taxonomy Proposal: Kind (Category), Sub-Kind (Variant), and Format (DLR_<KIND>_<SUBKIND>). This ensures strict naming conventions for all persisted artifacts.

ideas.title: Turing Gate Onboarding Pledge
ideas.description: Enhance engine/onboard.js with a semantic 'Turing Gate' that requires the Engineer to solve a protocol logic scenario before induction, ensuring deep alignment with the 'Integrity over Velocity' principle.

dialogue.text: I like the Turing Gate concept - can you provide some more detail on how this might work?

Refined into 'Induction Halt' mechanism: onboard.js pauses and directs the entity to the Oracle to study 'PRIME_DIRECTIVES'. A session-based 'Fidelity Handshake' token is generated to ensure the entity actively consults the Oracle before orientation is unlocked. Promoted to Backlog as FEAT_ZK_FIDELITY.

ideas.title: Strict Deliverable Taxonomy
ideas.description: Standardize and enforce strict naming conventions (DLR_<KIND>_<SUBKIND>) for all system deliverables to ensure predictability and machine-readability.

dialogue.text: I'd like to invoke IDEA for standardising strict naming conventions for all deliverables. A 'report' should be a 'kind' and there should be sub-kinds etc..

Proposed Taxonomy: DLR_<KIND>_<SUBKIND>. Example: 'DLR_RPT_COMPLIANCE' (Kind: Report, SubKind: Compliance). Strategy: 1. Audit registry for non-compliant IDs. 2. Rename/Migrate legacy IDs. 3. Enforce via validation script.
I'd like to consider the current naming we have for DLR items - and explore some options for a naming convention to standardise

Analyzed Options:
A) 3-Letter Kind (DLR_RPT_COMPLIANCE): Best for sortability and regex tooling. Consistent with system protocols.
B) Verb-Based (DLR_VERIFY_COMPLIANCE): Action-oriented but poor sorting and vocabulary consistency.
C) Domain-Based (DLR_GOV_HANDSHAKE): Groups by scope but fragments similar artifact types.

Recommendation: Option A for architectural rigidity and automation suitability.

ideas.title: Semantic Tooling & Schema Uplift

dialogue.text: Do any of the proposed improvements to the schema require specific upgrades to the tooling also to populate? Or does the ZK entity know how to complete these?
Analysis confirms ~60% of fields (hashes, duration, env stats) require tooling automation. Strategy defined: Phase A (Registry Schema Upgrade), Phase B (Tooling Automation for Metadata).

ideas.title: Interactive Onboarding Quiz
ideas.description: Explore ways for the Oracle to provide an interactive quiz for Engineers during the ONBOARD protocol to verify mastery of Prime Directives and system basics.

dialogue.text: I envisage that after the handshake process and reviewing the prime directives - that Oracle could ask the Engineer a series of questions (4-5?) that force the Angineer to analyse its understanding and provide a response back to Oracle to reinforce this understanding

Refined Proposal: Integrate `oracle.js quiz` module post-Prime Directives. 5 scenario-based questions requiring CLI input. Success grants `ZK_FIDELITY_CERT` token, now a hard requirement for Onboarding completion.

My initial concerns are for the ZK entity to acknowledge its obligations to adhere to strict protocol, and uphold Integrity-over-Velocity, and acknowledge that it must stop and wait for Director Approval gates

Adjustment: The Quiz content will be strictly scoped to these three pillars: 1) Protocol Adherence (The 'Why'), 2) Integrity-over-Velocity (The 'How'), and 3) Director Authority (The 'Stop'). The quiz will force the entity to explicitly type out affirmations of these duties, not just select options.

Refine / expand - beyond this initial "affirmations" we could also quiz the Engineer on tooling use for various scenarios, as well as Oracle use when more info required. Perhaps we structure this is a second quiz

Architecture Split: 
1) 'The Pledge' (Behavioral): Strict affirmation of obligations (Protocols, Integrity, Authority). 
2) 'The Exam' (Technical): Scenario-based challenges on Tooling (warden.js, gov.js) and Knowledge Retrieval (oracle.js). 
Implementation: 'The Pledge' is blocking for Onboarding. 'The Exam' is a requirement for the PRY_V2 Proficiency demonstration. Promoted to Backlog as FEAT_ORACLE_QUIZ.

ideas.title: Automated Remediation Engine (Warden Fixer)
ideas.description: Add a remediate command to Warden to automatically detect and fix common system regressions and technical debt.

dialogue.text: I think it should be an active command for now, we can move to passive later if desired. This should stay strictly within Governance Metadata (and never tooling code). I like each of the 4 points you make. Can you provide more detail on how #1 and #2 might work?

Refined Details for #1 & #2: 
#1 Registry Repair: Bi-directional referential integrity scan between protocols and deliverables. Level A (Fuzzy matching for near-miss IDs) and Level B (Automated stub generation for missing deliverables).
#2 Schema Alignment: Automated patching of implementer reports against High-Fidelity schemas, injecting missing fields and correcting structures while preserving content.

To prevent blind acceptance, the Fixer will not just output the anchors. It will present 'Candidate Anchors' and REQUIRE the Engineer to output a 'Strategic Rationale' for each before it generates the validation command. It transforms the Fixer from an 'Automator' to an 'Architectural Guide'.
Yes lets move to refine Capability #3

Refined Details for #3 Governance Debt Cleanup: Automated pruning of orphaned shadow snapshots, expired fidelity certificates, and non-referenced temporary states. The Fixer will maintain 'Tiered Persistence' by keeping core DNA (changelogs, knowledge base) while purging execution friction.

Refine. Ensure that any subdirectories within /registry are also not touched - in fact - can we expand to consider whether we need a dedicated centralised state directory and the impact this would have?

Refinement for #3 (State Centralization): To maximize structural integrity, the Fixer will now enforce a 'Centralized State Pattern'. All ephemeral execution files (.warden_active.json, .warden_session.log, .warden_quiz_cert.json) will be moved to a dedicated `.warden/state/` directory. Impact: 1) Simplifies cleanup (purge the whole dir). 2) Protects `registry/` from accidental pollution. 3) Standardizes paths for all future ZK entities. Promoted to Backlog as FEAT_WARDEN_FIXER via CON-005.

ideas.title: Modular Protocol Registry Architecture
ideas.description: Explore splitting the monolithic protocols.json into separate files within a dedicated registry/protocols/ directory to manage bloat and improve maintainability.

dialogue.text: I like this approach for modularity. Let's also expand to include verification/consistency/integrity checking/tool for the library. Let's maintain a flat copy for migration, and cleanup/remove post-migration.

Refined Proposal: 1) Implement 'Virtual Join' in GovernanceAPI. 2) Create 'registry/protocols/' directory. 3) Develop 'Warden Library Auditor' for cross-file referential integrity. 4) Use 'protocols.json' as a build-artifact (cached view) for migration, eventually deprecating it.
I like option 2 + 3. For #3 - which tool generates the manifest and when? I'd like for this manifest to include hashes of each protocol to provide a point of comparison for changes

Strategy for #3: The `finalizer.js` (during GSD Finalize) or a dedicated `lib_sync` command will invoke `audit_library.js --sync`. This will: 1) Scan all `registry/protocols/*.json`. 2) Calculate SHA-256 hashes for each. 3) Generate `registry/library_manifest.json` containing the protocol ID, version, file path, and hash. This manifest becomes the 'Integrity Baseline' for the verification phase.

ideas.title: Canonical Command Model & Structured Audit Uplift
ideas.description: Transition from string-based log matching to a structured, canonical command object model to eliminate audit friction and false negatives.

dialogue.text: Yes lets assign a generic 'system' id for this model. Also, should oracle blueprints be used here? If so, why or why not? As per standard, metadata-driven is key - please expand and provide more details/options on how this might work
Refine / expand. What other patterns might we require? Other tooling, oracle etc? I like Option A + B as described - does this meet the goal of the brittle issues we were facing earlier?

Expanded Intent Scope: We will include patterns for `engine/oracle.js` (e.g., `explain`, `quiz`, `blueprint`), `engine/patch.js` (e.g., `snapshot`, `save`, `restore`), and `docs/finalizer.js`. Crucially, we will also include 'Governance Proxy' patterns to detect when one tool (like Warden) invokes another. This solves the brittle matching goal because the 'Claim' no longer relies on the Engineer guessing a string; the Engineer simply cites the `intent.id` generated by the Warden. Option B (Halting on unknown intent) prevents 'Shadow Actions' from entering the audit trail, ensuring 100% observability.
Expand. Ensure oracle knowledge itself is codified to explain all of the new changes to the system. Also consider standards and glossary if updates are required

Holistic Codification: To ensure ZKE continuity, we will: 1) Add `INTENT_DRIVEN_LOGGING` to the System Glossary. 2) Codify a new standard `STD_CANONICAL_INTENT` in `standards.json`. 3) Expand `oracle.js` with topics for `CANONICAL_INTERACTION` and `INTENT_PATTERNS`. This ensures that any future Engineer can query the Oracle to understand why a command was halted or how to correctly cite an intent in their report. The knowledge base will be updated during the GSD Finalize phase to reflect the transition from string-matching to object-matching.
Refine/Expand - can we force the Engineer to provide additional justification and analysis for the Option B command use via the Cognitive Interjection?

Refined Option B (The Socratic Brake): When an unknown intent is detected, Warden will not just haltâ€”it will enter 'Mandatory Analysis Mode'. The command execution will be locked until the Engineer invokes `warden.js exec "<cmd>" --justify "<Analysis>"`. This justification must include: 1) Why the registered patterns are insufficient. 2) The architectural impact of the command. 3) A pledge to register the pattern if it becomes a recurring need. This justification is then auto-persisted to the session log as a `DLR_AUD_INTERJECTION` token, forcing the Engineer to 'Think' before they 'Shadow Action'. It transforms a technical failure into a governance opportunity.

ideas.title: Absolute Path Resolver Architecture
ideas.description: Redesign the path resolver to use a deterministic module pattern, supporting absolute project resolution and environment-based root overrides.

dialogue.text: Refine and expand - one goal of Warden is for it to be used as a system within an entire unrelated project. This could be a subdir within a different projcet - will this pathing capability support this goal?

Refined Proposal: 'External Root Anchor'. To support Warden as a subsystem, the new resolver will implement a 'Discovery Hierarchy'. It will look for a `.warden_root` anchor file or directory. If Warden is embedded in `other-project/tools/warden/`, the resolver will anchor to that specific subdirectory, ensuring its internal paths (registry/, engine/) remain relative to itself, while allowing its output (audit logs, patches) to optionally target the parent project root. This effectively transforms Warden into a portable 'Governance Container' that can be dropped into any directory structure without path breakage.
I like this expansion - it suits the goal nicely. Any additional areas strongly related to this we should consider in this refinement?

Related Area Expansion: 1) Path-Aware Auditing: The `verify_integrity.js` and `Library Auditor` will be updated to use the resolver to 'Ignore' files outside the target project root, preventing false-positive integrity failures when Warden is a submodule. 2) Env-Var Aliasing: Implement standardized environment aliases (e.g., `WARDEN_REGISTRY`, `WARDEN_STATE`) that the resolver will prioritize. This allows a ZK entity to re-map the entire system topology via a single `.env` file or shell session, which is critical for CI/CD pipeline integration and containerized execution.

ideas.title: Refine Cognitive Interjection (Metadata Presentation)
ideas.description: Design the metadata-driven presentation layer for Cognitive Interjection, including state-entry banners and automated Oracle guidance display.

dialogue.text: I'd prefer the banner to efficient and concise to not take up too much vertical room, but I also want it clear and obvious. How do you see the interjection working?

Refined Proposal: 'Turn-Boundary Interrupt'. To maintain efficiency, the banner will be a single-line high-contrast block (e.g., 'ðŸ›‘ [DIRECTOR GATE ACTIVE] ðŸ›‘'). The interjection will trigger at the end of the `warden.js next` command. Instead of just showing the next state, the Warden will: 1) Emit the concise banner. 2) Auto-synthesize the Oracle explanation for the new state. 3) Output a 'Cognitive Halt' token. This ensures that the very last things the ZK entity sees in the session log are the visual 'STOP' and the explicit instructions, maximizing the influence on its next-token generation without excessive vertical bloat.
Refine / expand. One issue we currently have is ZK entities providing a deliverable to the governance system, but not always echoing to the Director to review - can this JIT halt correct this?

The 'Double-Lock Affirmation': Yes, the JIT halt is the perfect mechanism to enforce this. I propose that for states requiring Director approval, the Warden will not only halt but will explicitly require a 'Delivery Handshake'. The banner will read: `ðŸ›‘ [HALT] DELIVERABLE GENERATED. PRESENT TO DIRECTOR NOW. ðŸ›‘`. The Warden will then refuse to advanced to the next state until it detects a `DLR_..._ACK` token from the Director. By placing this halt immediately after the deliverable is saved (e.g., in Phase 3), we physically block the entity from proceeding until they have performed the external echo. It transforms the Director from a 'Passive Observer' to an 'Active Gatekeeper' in the entity's primary loop.
